title: Mandy Moore's teenage years when she was a pop singer will be explored
text:
A drama series based on Mandy Moore's teenage pop fame will get a pilot at ABC.

The 35-year-old actress will executive produce it herself with Elizabeth Berger and Isaac Aptaker, who are co-showrunners on the actress' current ABC tearjerker series This Is Us.

Entitled 90s Popstar, the upcoming show is being written by Gossip Girl alumna Amanda Lasher, according to Deadline.

Incoming: A drama series based on Mandy Moore's teenage pop fame will get a pilot at ABC

Mandy grew up in a suburb of Orlando and became a famous pop act at the age of 15 after the release of her 1999 debut single Candy.

The pilot depicts the family in a small town in Florida and chronicles their reaction to their daughter's sudden childhood fame.

On top of showrunning This Is Us with its creator Dan Fogelman, Isaac and Elizabeth also wrote last year's gay teen romance movie Love, Simon.

They are now working on a TV show based on the film for Disney+ and 20th Century Fox, plus a Sarah Hyland multi-camera sitcom pilot at NBC.

Throwback: Mandy is pictured in February 2000 at 15, the age she was when she rose to notoriety after the release of her debut single Candy

Mandy was raised alongside two gay brothers, and when she was in her 20s her mother Stacy left her father Don for another woman.

In a 2006 interview with Cosmopolitan, Mandy looked back on her childhood and said: 'I don't think I had the aspiration to be a star growing up.'

The A Walk To Remember star said: 'I loved Madonna and Bette Midler, and I had my karaoke machine and would sing their songs.'

'She means business': This week Mandy shared a sweet childhood photo of herself with braces before she broke onto the pop scene

She also remembered when she shot to fame at the age of 15 and instantly found herself in a category with huge stars.

'When I was first starting out in the music industry, I was always coupled in the same sentence with Jessica Simpson, Britney Spears and Christina Aguilera - and I was probably the worst of them,' she said gamely.

'I think a lot of people back then thought, Mandy Moore...she'll probably go back to where she came from in a year,' shared the singer.
